summary: This is the U.S. Government's memorandum in support of pretrial detention for Ghislaine Maxwell, filed in the Southern District of New York. It argues she is an extreme flight risk due to the seriousness of the charges, strength of evidence, her substantial financial resources, multiple citizenships, international connections, and lack of meaningful ties to the United States.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Charged with conspiracy to entice and transport minors for illegal sex acts and perjury, alleged to have been a close associate of Jeffrey Epstein and played a key role in grooming and abusing underage girls.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Described as a serial sexual predator with whom Maxwell partnered to exploit and abuse young girls. Financial transfers between his accounts and Maxwell's are noted.

persons.name: Audrey Strauss
persons.context: Signed the government's detention memorandum as the Acting U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of New York.

connections.description: Described as having a personal and professional partnership in a scheme to sexually abuse underage girls. Maxwell is labeled one of Epstein's closest associates.
Between 2007 and 2011, approximately more than $20 million was transferred from accounts associated with Epstein to accounts associated with Maxwell, with some funds transferred back.

events.title: Alleged Sexual Abuse Scheme
events.description: Maxwell and Epstein allegedly conspired to sexually abuse underage girls at Epstein's properties in New York, Florida, and New Mexico.

events.title: Maxwell's Deposition Testimony
events.description: Maxwell gave deposition testimony in a civil lawsuit in the SDNY, where she is alleged to have repeatedly lied under oath about her role in facilitating the abuse of minors.

events.title: Sale of NYC Residence
events.description: Maxwell sold a New York City residence for $15 million through an LLC, with over $14 million subsequently deposited into an account in her name.

events.title: Epstein Indictment Unsealed / Maxwell Goes into Hiding
events.description: After the indictment against Jeffrey Epstein was unsealed, Maxwell stopped appearing in public and began hiding in locations in New England.

events.title: Purchase of New Hampshire Property
events.description: A 156-acre property in Bradford, New Hampshire, was acquired in an all-cash purchase through an anonymized LLC, where Maxwell was reportedly hiding.

events.title: Grand Jury Returns Indictment
events.description: A federal grand jury in the SDNY returned a sealed indictment charging Maxwell with multiple counts related to the sexual exploitation of minors and perjury.

locations: New York City (location of sold residence)
keyFacts: The government alleges Ghislaine Maxwell played a key role in Jeffrey Epstein's abuse of minors by identifying, grooming, and facilitating the abuse of girls as young as 14 between 1994 and 1997.
Maxwell is charged with serious crimes carrying a potential statutory maximum of 35 years in prison, creating a strong incentive to flee.

Maxwell possesses three passports (U.S., U.K., and French), has engaged in frequent international travel, and has access to substantial financial resources, including bank accounts holding up to $20 million.

After Epstein's indictment was unsealed in July 2019, Maxwell went into hiding, moving locations, switching contact information, and was found on a recently purchased, anonymized property in New Hampshire.
The government's evidence includes detailed accounts from multiple victims corroborated by flight records, diary entries, business records, and witness testimony.
